text: what are you making for dinner tonight
how about a great recipe for sauteed
chicken cutlets with herbs the great
thing about sauteing recipes is once you
learn the technique you can adapt it
however you want so today we're using
chicken tomorrow you might want to use
turkey cutlets or pork or veal the same
technique will work for all of those and
I'm going to show you how to do it
first what you want to do is season your
chicken with salt and pepper on both
sides I'm going to use tongs in an
effort not to touch the rock chicken see
how that goes sometimes I forget and
touch it anyway and I have eight chicken
cutlets these are the nice thin chicken
cutlets that I got from the store you
can make your own chicken cutlets by
cutting boneless chicken breast halves
in half and then pounding them since I'm
using coarse salt like I like to do
because it spreads around really nicely
and it's really easy to pick up between
your fingers and then when they're nice
and seasoned quarter cup of flour in a
plate that's big enough to dredge the
chicken and then you want to just coat
them nicely in flour that's what I mean
by dredge lightly coat and then shake
off the excess both sides shake back on
your cutting board I'm managing to keep
my hands out of it this time I'm pretty
happy the flour is great it's going to
help the Browning of the chicken cutlets
because these are really thin and they
don't cook that long and the flour helps
to brown and it also helps to thicken
the sauce so it serves two purposes here
taking these and I'm taking this and I'm
going to the stove all right here I come
my chicken down
I want to heat my pan I like to start
heating it a little bit early so that it
starts getting nice and hot you want an
immediate sizzle when you add your
chicken a little bit of olive oil about
a tablespoon you're probably going to
need to cook these in batches because
you want them in a single layer in the
pan don't try to cram them all in there
it will not be a pretty sight in the pan
it's smoking hot it's gonna sizzle we
should only take about one to two
minutes per side but while they're
cooking you can get the rest of your
ingredients ready which is barely any
ingredients it's a little bit of herb
and a little bit of butter and a little
bit of wine I'm going to need 3/4 of a
cup of wine so I'm just going to open
that now nice dry wine and now those
babies are ready to turn let's turn them
see how they're just a little bit gold
in there that's from the flour that's
what you're looking for and then another
1 to 2 minutes and they'll be done so I
think these are ready to take out it can
be just like
they're done because they're going to go
back in with the sauce for a couple of
seconds at the end and they'll finish
cooking them so take them out okay now
while this batch is cooking I'm going to
chop my herbs and get my butter ready so
two tablespoons of butter not that much
but it adds a nice richness and help
thicken the sauce and then three
tablespoons of chopped herbs you can use
parsley or mint or combination or
cilantro whatever you really want I'm
going to use parsley and mint and then
just chop it doesn't have to be too fine
the more elegant you want it the finer
you should chop it it really helps if
your herbs are dry and your knife is
sharp then you get the best chop but you
want to make sure that you wash your
herbs because they can be very gritty so
wash them and dry them really well the
cutlets are ready to turn actually take
them out of the pan add one more batch
the last batch so I have this on
medium-high because I want the chicken
to cook and get nice and brown but I
don't want the pan to burn because we're
going to use those brown bits on the bun
in the pan to make our sauce get rid of
this straight to the dishwasher
or into the thing you caught me gotta go
in the dishwasher
stop it I'm turning the last fat couple
more minutes and we're going to deglaze
so do you see that these brown bits are
brown but they're not burnt that's
exactly what you're looking for cuz you
want them to taste delicious because
they're going into your sauce but add
your wine right away isn't that insane
it comes down really quickly but it is
quite dramatic when you had one that was
3/4 of a cup of wine and you want to let
it cook until it reduces by about half
that should take about four minutes but
sometimes if your pan is really hot it
might take less time deglazing is adding
hot liquid to a hot pan and then
stirring with a spoon to get any of the
brown bits up from the bottom of the pan
its reduced by half so now you'll add
your chicken back into the simmering
liquid and the flour that's left on the
chicken is going to thicken the sauce
shake it just a tiny bit you turn to
coat these what you're getting is a nice
sauce but not a lot of sauce turn it off
and then add your butter and your herbs
and then you just swirl it around to
coat so nice coach the chicken exactly
the way you want not too much not too
little and you can use this method for
any cut approaching that you want that's

can you believe it wasn't that easy it's

so nice
then just put all your chicken on the

before you put it on the platter and
